param.name: query_field
param.label: Fields
param.option: Used in a standard entry that serves as primary source for a TSA entry acc#.
Reference to the annotated genome contigs
Reference to the annotated genome contigs
Reference to the annotated genome contigs
Reference to the annotated genome contigs
ENSEMBL accession (only for studies based on ENSEMBL such as Proteomics)
Cross-reference to Ensembl's gene tree view, but currently the reference doesn't exist in Ensembl.
The interpro parent of this entry.
Cross-reference to G-protein-coupled receptor in IUPHAR
Cross-reference to G-protein-coupled receptor in IUPHAR
References to the Organism host taxonomy
Internal UniProt reference to a rule base
Cross-reference to Xenopus Anatomical Ontology. Flat file can be found at: http://obo.cvs.sourceforge.net/obo/obo/ontology/anatomy/gross_anatomy/animal_gross_anatomy/frog/xenopus_anatomy.obo
Defines an alternate id for this term.
Assay classification, e.g. B=Binding assay, A=ADME assay, F=Functional assay
Canonical smiles, generated using pipeline pilot
Centre or institute name of the submitter.
For ions the magnitude of the charge
Gives a term which may be an appropriate substitute for an obsolete term, but needs to be looked at carefully by a human expert before the replacement is done.
Protein name this cross reference is referring to
Source organism this cross reference is referring to
The UniProt id this cross reference is referring to
The date when it first becomes available for searching in NLM's online databases, such as PubMed
Controlled vocabulary which expresses the overall purpose and focus for the study.
A link to the ftp location of the data files for that variant
The original link of the dataset
Relationship between two molecular entities (or classes of entities), one of which possesses one or more characteristic groups from which the other can be derived by functional modification.

Relationship between an entity and its parent hydride (defined by IUPAC as "an unbranched acyclic or cyclic structure or an acyclic/cyclic structure having a semisystematic or trivial name to which only hydrogen atoms are attached").
Used to indicate relationship between part and whole
Indicates the particular behaviour which an entity may exhibit, either naturally or by human application.
Name and model of the instrument upon which the sequencing experiment was carried out.
Instrument platform is used to classify the instruments use for example (5975C Series GC/MSD, Orbitrap), etc.
The value is the id of the term of which this term is a subclass.
Cyclic relationships used to connect acids with their conjugate bases.
Cyclic relationships used to connect acids with their conjugate bases.
A cyclic relationship used in instances when two entities are mirror images of and non-superposable upon each other.
Whether or not this term is obsoleteid (0 or 1).
May be set to true if this is a root in the current ontology id (0 or 1)
Relationship between a substituent group (or atom) and its parent molecular entity, from which it is formed by loss of one or more protons or simple groups such as hydroxy groups.
A cyclic relationship used to show the interrelationship between two tautomers, where the differences between the structures are significant enough to warrant their separate inclusion in ChEBI.
ISSN eight-character value that uniquely identifies the cited journal
Name of the library as given by the submitter.
Controlled vocabulary which describes the method of selection or enrichment of the source material.
Controlled vocabulary which describes the molecule type of the source material used in the sequencing.
Controlled vocabulary which describes the sequencing technique applied to the library.
New term to be considered for inclusion within the existing_study_type list. This is used when the existing_study_type is "Other".
Number of families in a clan
Number of sequence regions annotated in a family
Number of sequences in seed alignment
Omics type (for example Metabolomics, Proteomics, Genomics)
Taxonomic classification of the source organism (OC line)
Organism host species (OH line of the flat file)
Preferred scientific name of the organism (OS line)
Relationship 'part_of'. The value is a GO term id.
Relationship 'positively_regulates'. The value is a GO term id.
Protein Existence (PE line of the flat file)
the history of changes in the record
Relationship 'regulates'. The value is a GO term id.
Gives a term which replaces an obsolete term. The value is the id of the replacement term.
Here are listed the IDs of any entries which may have been subsumed into the parent.
Last modification date of the sequence
Standardised version of the published activity type (e.g. IC50 rather than Ic-50/Ic50/ic50/ic-50)
Same as published value but transformed to common units (e.g. All concentration values are converted to values in nM)
The accession id for the study
Study design used in Metaboligths and ISATAB with ontolgies
Study factor in ISATab and other resources to catalog the experimental factors involved
Study status (only for Metabolomics studies but it can be also included in Proteomics)
Keywords provider by the submitter or the original resource
This tag indicates a term subset to which this term belongs.
In contrast to the accepted name a more systematic name

Technology type provides the information about the technology in metabolomics could be mass spectrometry, NMR spectroscopy, NMR spectroscopy, or can be MRM in proteomics or experiment type in proteomics
Tissue used to describe the tissue used in the experiment
The sample the variant belongs to. A variant may have a null sample
The type associated with the variant

param.label: Fields
param.option: For ions the magnitude of the charge
Relationship between two molecular entities (or classes of entities), one of which possesses one or more characteristic groups from which the other can be derived by functional modification.

Relationship between an entity and its parent hydride (defined by IUPAC as "an unbranched acyclic or cyclic structure or an acyclic/cyclic structure having a semisystematic or trivial name to which only hydrogen atoms are attached").
Used to indicate relationship between part and whole
Indicates the particular behaviour which an entity may exhibit, either naturally or by human application.
Implies that 'Entity A' is an instance of 'Entity B'
Cyclic relationships used to connect acids with their conjugate bases.
Cyclic relationships used to connect acids with their conjugate bases.
A cyclic relationship used in instances when two entities are mirror images of and non-superposable upon each other.
Relationship between a substituent group (or atom) and its parent molecular entity, from which it is formed by loss of one or more protons or simple groups such as hydroxy groups.
A cyclic relationship used to show the interrelationship between two tautomers, where the differences between the structures are significant enough to warrant their separate inclusion in ChEBI.
IUPAC representation of the chemical entity
Here are listed the IDs of any entries which may have been subsumed into the parent.
Alternative names for an entity which either have been used in EBI or external sources or have been devised by the curators based on recommendations of IUPAC, NC-IUBMB or their associated bodies.

May be set to true if this is a root in the current ontology id (0 or 1)
A label identifying the ontology (the domain) the term belongs to.
Relationship 'part_of'. The value is a GO term id.
Relationship 'positively_regulates'. The value is a GO term id.
Relationship 'regulates'. The value is a GO term id.
Gives a term which replaces an obsolete term. The value is the id of the replacement term.
This tag indicates a term subset to which this term belongs.
This tag gives a synonym for the term.

param.name: query_field
param.label: Fields
param.option: Assay classification, e.g. B=Binding assay, A=ADME assay, F=Functional assay
Canonical smiles, generated using pipeline pilot
For ions the magnitude of the charge
Relationship between two molecular entities (or classes of entities), one of which possesses one or more characteristic groups from which the other can be derived by functional modification.

Relationship between an entity and its parent hydride (defined by IUPAC as "an unbranched acyclic or cyclic structure or an acyclic/cyclic structure having a semisystematic or trivial name to which only hydrogen atoms are attached").
Used to indicate relationship between part and whole
Indicates the particular behaviour which an entity may exhibit, either naturally or by human application.
Implies that 'Entity A' is an instance of 'Entity B'
Cyclic relationships used to connect acids with their conjugate bases.
Cyclic relationships used to connect acids with their conjugate bases.
A cyclic relationship used in instances when two entities are mirror images of and non-superposable upon each other.
Relationship between a substituent group (or atom) and its parent molecular entity, from which it is formed by loss of one or more protons or simple groups such as hydroxy groups.
A cyclic relationship used to show the interrelationship between two tautomers, where the differences between the structures are significant enough to warrant their separate inclusion in ChEBI.
IUPAC representation of the chemical entity
Source organism of molecular target or tissue, or the target organism if compound activity is reported in an organism rather than a protein or tissue
Here are listed the IDs of any entries which may have been subsumed into the parent.
Standardised version of the published activity type (e.g. IC50 rather than Ic-50/Ic50/ic50/ic-50)
Same as published value but transformed to common units (e.g. All concentration values are converted to values in nM)
Alternative names for an entity which either have been used in EBI or external sources or have been devised by the curators based on recommendations of IUPAC, NC-IUBMB or their associated bodies.

param.label: Field to export
param.option: Assay classification, e.g. B=Binding assay, A=ADME assay, F=Functional assay
Canonical smiles, generated using pipeline pilot
IUPAC representation of the chemical entity
Source organism of molecular target or tissue, or the target organism if compound activity is reported in an organism rather than a protein or tissue
Standardised version of the published activity type (e.g. IC50 rather than Ic-50/Ic50/ic50/ic-50)
Same as published value but transformed to common units (e.g. All concentration values are converted to values in nM)
